title: Choosing the Best Canon RF Lens for Portrait Photography
summary: Portrait and fashion photographer Lindsay Adler provides professional insights into three of Canon's popular RF lenses—the 85mm f/1.2, 24-105mm f/2.8, and 70-200mm f/2.8. She breaks down the strengths, weaknesses, and ideal use cases for each to help photographers choose the right tool for their specific style.

steps.action: Introduction to the three lenses being reviewed: RF 85mm f/1.2, RF 24-105mm f/2.8, and RF 70-200mm f/2.8.
Review of the RF 85mm f/1.2. Highlights its ability to create extremely narrow depth of field and beautiful bokeh, making it ideal for isolating subjects and low-light shooting.
Review of the RF 24-105mm f/2.8. Discusses its high versatility for fast-paced studio work, allowing for full-length to close-up shots without changing lenses.
Comparison between the 24-105mm f/2.8 and f/4 versions. Weighs the benefits of the extra stop of light and sharpness against the lower price and lighter weight of the f/4 version.
Review of the RF 70-200mm f/2.8. Explains its strength in creating background compression for outdoor shoots and achieving tight framing for beauty photography.
Final summary and recommendations. Advises choosing the 85mm for bokeh, the 24-105mm for versatility, and the 70-200mm for compression and tight shots.

key_takeaways: The RF 85mm f/1.2 is the best choice for photographers who prioritize creamy bokeh and shooting in low light, though it lacks zoom versatility.
The RF 24-105mm is the ultimate 'workhorse' lens, offering the most versatility for photographers who need to change framing quickly.
The RF 70-200mm is ideal for controlling the environment through background compression and is excellent for tight beauty headshots.
When choosing between f/2.8 and f/4 zooms, consider if the extra stop of light and marginal sharpness increase is worth the significant difference in price and weight.
